original: sakṛdāgāmiphalaḥ /🔽śraddhavimuktirdṛṣṭiprāpta ekavīcīko'nāgāmyantarāparinirvāyī upahatyaparinirvāyī abhisaṃskāraparinirvāyī pluto'rddhaplutaḥ sarvāstānapluto dṛṣṭadharmasamaḥ kāyasākṣī khaṅgaśceti //🔽tadanu dvādaśākaradharmacakrapravartakaṃnaṃ🔽katamat / tadyathāidaṃ duḥkhamāryasatyamiti bhikṣavaḥ pūrvamanuśrutya teṣu dharmeṣu yoniśo manasiṃgavataḥ /
analyzed: śraddhā vimuktiḥ dṛṣṭi prāptaḥ ekavīcīkaḥ nāgāmī antarā parinirvāyī upahatya parinirvāyī abhisaṃskāra parinirvāyī pluta ūrddhaplutaḥ sarvāstānaplutaḥ dṛṣṭadharmasamaḥ kāya sākṣī khaṅgaḥ ca iti  tadanu  katamat tat yathā idam duḥkham ārya satyam iti bhikṣavaḥ pūrvam anuśrutya teṣu dharmeṣu yoniśas manasiṃgavataḥ

original: cakṣurudapādi /🔽jñānamutpādi cintotpādi /🔽cutrirudapādi /🔽ityekaparicatakaḥ idaṃ duḥkhamārya sa tatra khalvabhijñātaṃ iti bhikṣavaḥ /🔽ityādi pūrvavaditiyaḥ //🔽idaṃ duḥkhasamudayamāryasatvaṃ tava khalvabhijñāya prahīṇamiti hityādi tṛtīyaḥ /
analyzed: cakṣuḥ udapādi 🔽jñānam utpādi cintā utpādi 🔽cutriḥ udapādi 🔽iti eka paricatakaḥ idam duḥkham ārya sa tatra khalu abhijñātam iti bhikṣavaḥ 🔽ityādi pūrvavat itiyaḥ 🔽idam duḥkha samudayam ārya satvam tava khalu abhijñāya prahīṇam iti hi tyādi tṛtīyaḥ
translated: One liberated by faith, one attained to view, one of single progress, a non-returner who attains final nirvana in the intermediate state, one who attains final nirvana with effort, one who attains final nirvana without effort, one who leaps over, one who leaps over half, one who leaps over all, one who attains final nirvana in this very life, one who is a body witness, and one who is a rhinoceros.

original: tathā idaṃ duḥkhanirodha āryasatyamiti hipratyekaḥ //🔽idaṃ duḥkhanirodhaāryyasatyaṃ tatra khalvabhijñāya śākṣāt kartavyamiti hitya dvitīyaḥ /
analyzed: tathā idam duḥkha nirodhaḥ ārya satyam iti hi pratyekaḥ  idam duḥkha nirodha ārya satyam tatra khalu abhijñāya śākṣāt kartavyam iti dvitīyaḥ
translated: Thus, this is the noble truth of the cessation of suffering, each one.🔽This is the noble truth of the cessation of suffering, monks, which should be fully understood. Thus, the second.

original: idaṃ duḥkhanirodhaāryasatya tatra khalu bhijñāya śākṣāt dvitīya /
translated: This is the noble truth of the cessation of suffering, monks, which should be fully understood.

analyzed: tat yathā idam duḥkha mārga gāminī
translated: Just as this is the noble truth of the path leading to the cessation of suffering, each one.

original: idaṃ duḥkhamokṣagāmini pratipa ityāryyasatyaṃ tatra khalu bhijñāya bhāvayitavyamiti hi bhikṣava ityādi tṛtīyaḥ /
analyzed: idam duḥkha mokṣa gāmini pratipe iti āryya satyam tatra khalu bhijñāya bhāvayitavyam iti hi bhikṣavaḥ ityādi tṛtīyaḥ
translated: This is the noble truth of the path leading to the cessation of suffering, monks, which should be fully understood and cultivated. Thus, the third, monks.

analyzed: parivartaḥ iti eva dvādaśa ākāra dharma cakra pravarttanam iti
translated: The chapter is thus called the turning of the wheel of Dharma with twelve aspects.
After that, the one who turns the wheel of Dharma with twelve aspects.

analyzed: idam duḥkham ārya satyam iti bhikṣavaḥ
translated: Monks, this is the noble truth of suffering.

original: pūrvamanuśrutya teṣu dharmeṣu yoniśo manasigavataḥ cakṣurudapādi /
analyzed: pūrvam anuśrutya teṣu dharmeṣu yoniśas manasigavataḥ cakṣuḥ udapādi
translated: Having previously heard, when one properly contemplates those dharmas, the eye arises.

original: ityekaparivartaka idaṃ duḥkhamāryasatyaṃ tatra khalvabhijñāya parijñātamiti hi bhikṣavaḥ /
analyzed: iti eka parivartake idam duḥkham ārya satyam tatra khalu abhijñāya parijñātam iti hi bhikṣavaḥ
translated: Thus, this is the noble truth of suffering. There, indeed, it has been fully understood by direct knowledge. Thus, monks,
Having heard it before, he applied his mind properly.

analyzed: idam ārya satyam tatra khalu abhijñātam iti bhikṣavaḥ
translated: This is the noble truth of suffering. There, indeed, it has been fully understood by direct knowledge. Thus, monks,

original: idaṃ duḥkhasamudayamāryasatyaṃ tava khalvabhijñāya prahīṇamiti hītyādi tṛtīyam //
analyzed: idam duḥkha samudayam ārya satyam tava khalu abhijñāya prahīṇam iti hi ityādi tṛtīyam
translated: This is the noble truth of the arising of suffering. There, indeed, it has been abandoned by direct knowledge. Thus, the third.

original: tathā idaṃ duḥkhanirodha āryasatyamiti hi pratyekaḥ //
analyzed: tathā idam duḥkha nirodhaḥ ārya satyam iti hi pratyekaḥ
translated: Similarly, this is the noble truth of the cessation of suffering. Each one.

original: idaṃ duḥkhanirodha āryasatyaṃ tatra khalvabhijñāya sākṣāt kartavyamiti hityādi /🔽dvitīyaḥ /
analyzed: idam duḥkha nirodhe ārya satyam tatra khalu abhijñāya sākṣāt kartavyam iti hi tyādi  dvitīyaḥ
translated: This is the noble truth of the cessation of suffering. There, indeed, it should be realized by direct knowledge. Thus, the second.

original: idaṃ duḥkhanirodha āryasatyaṃ tatra khalvabhijñāya sākṣāt kṛtamiti dvitīyaḥ /
analyzed: idam duḥkha nirodhaḥ ārya satyam tatra khalu abhijñāya sākṣāt kṛtam iti dvitīyaḥ
translated: This is the noble truth of the cessation of suffering. There, indeed, it has been realized by direct knowledge. Thus, the second.

analyzed: tathā idam duḥkha mārga gāmini pratipad ārya satyam iti
translated: Similarly, this is the noble truth of the path leading to the cessation of suffering. Each one.
This is the path leading to the cessation of suffering.

original: idaṃ duḥkhasamudayamāryasatyaṃ tatra khalvabhijñāya prahātavyamiti dvitīyam /
analyzed: idam duḥkha samudayam ārya satyam tatra khalu abhijñāya prahātavyam iti dvitīyam
translated: This is the noble truth of the arising of suffering. Having fully known it, it should be abandoned. This is the second.

original: idaṃ duḥkhasamudayamāryasatyaṃ tatra khalvabhijñāya prahīṇamiti hītyādi tṛtīyam /
analyzed: idam duḥkha samudayam ārya satyam tatra khalu abhijñāya prahīṇam iti hi ityādi tṛtīyam
translated: This is the noble truth of the arising of suffering. Having fully known it, it has been abandoned. This is the third, and so on.

analyzed: tathā idam duḥkha nirodham ārya satyam iti hi pratyekam
translated: Similarly, this is the noble truth of the cessation of suffering. Each one.

original: idaṃ duḥkhanirodhamāryasatyaṃ tatra khalvabhijñāya sākṣātkartavyamiti hītyādi dvitīyam /
analyzed: idam duḥkha nirodham ārya satyam tatra khalu abhijñāya sākṣātkartavyam iti hi ityādi dvitīyam
translated: This is the noble truth of the cessation of suffering. Having fully known it, it should be realized. This is the second, and so on.

original: idaṃ duḥkhanirodhamāryasatyaṃ tatra khalvabhijñāya sākṣātkṛtamiti tṛtīyam //
analyzed: idam duḥkha nirodham ārya satyam tatra khalu abhijñāya sākṣātkṛtam iti tṛtīyam
translated: This is the noble truth of the cessation of suffering. Having fully known it, it has been realized. This is the third.

analyzed: tathā iyam duḥkha mārga gāminī pratipad iti ārya satyam iti pratyekam
translated: Similarly, this is the noble truth of the path leading to the cessation of suffering. Each one.

original: iyaṃ duḥkhamokṣagāminī pratipadityāryasatyaṃ tatra khalvabhivijñāya bhāvayitavyamiti hi bhikṣava ityādi dvitīyam /
analyzed: iyam duḥkha mokṣa gāminī pratipad iti ārya satyam tatra khalu abhivijñāya bhāvayitavyam iti hi bhikṣavaḥ ityādi dvitīyam
translated: This is the noble truth of the path leading to the cessation of suffering. Having fully known it, it should be developed. This is the second, monks, and so on.

original: idaṃ duḥkhamokṣagāminī pratipadityāryasatyaṃ tatra khalvabhijñāya bhāvitamiti tṛtīyam //
analyzed: idam duḥkha mokṣa gāminī pratipad iti ārya satyam tatra khalu abhijñāya bhāvitam iti tṛtīyam
translated: This is the noble truth of the path leading to the cessation of suffering. Having fully known it, it has been developed. This is the third.

analyzed: tat yathā saṃbhāra śīlam  kuśala saṃgrāha śīlam
translated: namely, the morality of accumulation,🔽the morality of collecting virtue,

analyzed: sattva artha kriyā śīlam ca iti
translated: and the morality of benefiting beings.
namely, the patience of contemplating phenomena,

analyzed: para upakāra dharma kṣāntiḥ ca iti
translated: and the patience of benefiting others.

analyzed: tat yathā saṃnāha vīryam  prayoga vīryam parari
translated: namely, the effort of armor,🔽the effort of application,

analyzed: tat yathā a sa doṣa apakarṣa dhyānam
translated: namely, the meditation of removing faults,
and the meditation of being adorned with everything.
namely, that which comes from hearing,
and that which comes from cultivation.
namely, that which awakens all beings,
that which accomplishes the welfare of beings,
and that which quickly and easily attains enlightenment.
namely, those that are always continuous,
those that are continuous for the sake of beings,
and those that purify the Buddha-fields.
For example, it turns away from actions.

analyzed: māna pramāda ādi vyāvartakam ca iti
translated: And it turns away from pride, heedlessness, and so on.
For example, it is non-conceptual.🔽It teaches the equality of conceptualization.

analyzed: satya artha upāya parokṣam ca iti
translated: And it is devoted to the means of knowing the truth.
For example, the obscuration of afflictions.
And the obscuration to the knowable.

analyzed: nairātmyam dvividham  tat yathā dharma nairātmyam
translated: Selflessness is twofold.🔽For example, the selflessness of phenomena.
For example, the accumulation of merit.
Therein, there are six obscurations to concentration.
Therein, the eight applications are the applications of abandonment.
For example, Videha in the east.
Namely, the surface of the earth,

analyzed: tat yathā cakravāla mahā cakravālau ca iti

translated: There are six gods in the desire realm.
Eighteen gods of the form realm.
Four gods of the formless realm.
Those who go to the sphere of infinite space.
Those who go to the sphere of infinite consciousness.
Those who go to the sphere of nothingness.

analyzed: na eva saṃjñā na asaṃjñā āyatana upagāḥ ca iti
translated: Those who go to the sphere of neither perception nor non-perception.

analyzed: trividhāḥ ālaṅghanāḥ  tat yathā asatyā ālaṅghanā
translated: Three kinds of transcendence.🔽Namely, transcendence of truth.

analyzed: trividhā mahāmaitrī  tat yathā asatya ālaṅghamba
translated: Three kinds of great friendliness.🔽Namely, transcendence of truth.
Namely, karma to be experienced in this very life.
To be experienced in the next life,
and to be experienced in a subsequent life.

analyzed: trividham prātihāryam  tat yathā ṛddhi prātihāryam  ādeśanā prātihāryam
translated: There are three kinds of miracles:🔽The miracle of psychic power,🔽the miracle of reading others' minds,

analyzed: aṣṭa akṣaṇāḥ  tat yathā naraka upapattiḥ  tiryak upapattiḥ
translated: There are eight inopportune times:🔽Being born in hell,🔽being born as an animal,🔽being born in the realm of hungry ghosts,

analyzed: yama loka upapattiḥ  pratyanta janapada upapattiḥ
translated: being born in a border region,
being born as a long-lived god,

analyzed: citta utpāda virāgi tatā ca iti
translated: and having a mind that is not inclined towards enlightenment.

analyzed: trividhāḥ vikalpāḥ  tat yathā anusmaraṇa vikalpaḥ
translated: There are three kinds of conceptualization:
There are four concentrations:🔽The heroic stride,
the sky treasury, the stainless light,

analyzed: caturdaśa avyākṛta vastūni  tat yathā aśāśvataḥ lokaḥ
translated: There are fourteen indeterminate topics:🔽The world is eternal,

analyzed: aśāśvataḥ lokaḥ  śāśvataḥ ca a śāśvataḥ ca
translated: the world is not eternal,🔽the world is both eternal and not eternal,

analyzed: na eva śāśvataḥ na a śāśvataḥ ca
translated: the world is neither eternal nor not eternal.
The world has an end,🔽the world has no end,🔽the world has both an end and no end,
the world has neither an end nor no end.

analyzed: na eva antavān na anantavān ca

original: na bhavati tathāgataḥ paraṃ maraṇāt /🔽bhavati na ca bhavati ca tathāgataḥ paraṃ maraṇāt /
analyzed: na bhavati tathāgataḥ param maraṇāt  bhavati na ca bhavati ca tathāgataḥ param maraṇāt
translated: The Tathāgata does not exist after death.🔽The Tathāgata both exists and does not exist after death.

original: naiva bhavati na bhavati tathāgataḥ paraṃ maraṇāt /🔽sa jīvastaccharīram /
analyzed: na eva bhavati na bhavati tathāgataḥ param maraṇāt  sa jīvaḥ tat śarīram
translated: The Tathāgata neither exists nor does not exist after death.🔽The soul is the same as the body.

analyzed: anyaḥ jīvaḥ anyat śarīram ca iti
translated: The soul is different from the body.
There are three roots of virtue.

analyzed: amohaḥ ca iti  etad viparyayāt trīṇi akuśalamūlāni
translated: and non-delusion.🔽The opposite of these are the three roots of non-virtue.

analyzed: tisraḥ śikṣāḥ  tat yathā adhicitta śikṣā
translated: There are three trainings.🔽They are the training in higher mind,
and the training in higher wisdom.

analyzed: iti nāgārjuna pāda viracitaḥ yam dharma saṃgrahaḥ samāptaḥ
translated: Thus, this Dharma-Compendium composed by the feet of Nāgārjuna is complete.
